column4: I naturally am aware of it
column5: because I
column6: of course
column7: pay attention to everything Senator Kennedy says
column8: as well as Senator Fulbright. Now
column9: in this connection I want to point out that the facts simply aren't as stated. First of all
column10: the report to which Senator Kennedy refers is one that was made many
column11: many months ago and related particularly to the uh - period immediately after Sputnik. Second
column12: as far as this report is concerned
column13: I would have no objection to having it made public. Third
column14: I would say this with regard to this report
column15: with regard to Gallup Polls of prestige abroad and everything else that we've been hearing about ""what about American prestige abroad"": America's prestige abroad will be just as high as the spokesmen for America allow it to be. Now
column16: when we have a presidential candidate
column17: for example - Senator Kennedy - stating over and over again that the United States is second in space and the fact of the matter is that the space score today is twenty-eight to eight - we've had twenty-eight successful shots
column18: they've had eight; when he states that we're second in education
column19: and I have seen Soviet education and I've seen ours
column20: and we're not; that we're second in science because they may be ahead in one area or another
column21: when overall we're way ahead of the Soviet Union and all other countries in science; when he says as he did in January of this year that we have the worst slums
column22: that we have the most crowded schools; when he says that seventeen million people go to bed hungry every night; when he makes statements like this
column23: what does this do to American prestige? Well
column24: it can only have the effect certainly of reducing it. Well let me make one thing clear. Senator Kennedy has a responsibility to criticize those things that are wrong
column25: but he has also a responsibility to be right in his criticism. Every one of these items that I have mentioned he's been wrong - dead wrong. And for that reason he has contributed to any lack of prestige. Finally
column26: let me say this: as far as prestige is concerned
column27: the first place it would show up would be in the United Nations. Now Senator Kennedy has referred to the vote on Communist China. Let's look at the vote on Hungary. There we got more votes for condemning Hungary and looking into that situation than we got the last year. Let's look at the reaction eh - reaction to Khrushchev and Eisenhower at the last U.N. session. Did Khrushchev gain because he took his shoe off and pounded the table and shouted and insulted? Not at all. The President gained. America gained by continuing the dignity
column28: the decency that has characterized us and it's that that keeps the prestige of America up
column29: not running down America the way Senator Kennedy has been running her down.

column1: I really don't need uh - Mr. Nixon to tell me about what my responsibilities are as a citizen. I've served this country for fourteen years in the Congress and before that in the service. I've just as high a devotion
column2: just as high an opinion. What I downgrade
column4: is the leadership the country is getting
column5: not the country. Now I didn't make most of the statements that you said I made. The s- I believe the Soviet Union is first in outer space. We have - may have made more shots but the size of their rocket thrust and all the rest - you yourself said to Khrushchev
column6: ""You may be ahead of us in rocket thrust but we're ahead of you in color television"" in your famous discussion in the kitchen. I think that color television is not as important as rocket thrust. Secondly
column7: I didn't say we had the worst slums in the world. I said we had too many slums. And that they are bad
column8: and we ought to do something about them
column9: and we ought to support housing legislation which this Administration has opposed. I didn't say we had the worst education in the world. What I said was that ten years ago
column10: we were producing twice as many scientists and engineers as the Soviet Union and today they're producing twice as many as we are
column11: and that this affects our security around the world. And fourth
column12: I believe that the polls and other studies and votes in the United Nations and anyone reading the paper and any citizen of the United States must come to the conclusion that the United States no longer carries the same image of a vital society on the move with its brightest days ahead as it carried a decade or two decades ago. Part of that is because we've stood still here at home
column13: because we haven't met our problems in the United States
column14: because we haven't had a moving economy. Part of that
column15: as the Gallup Polls show
column16: is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space. Mr. George Allen
column17: head of your Information Service
column18: has said that that made the people of the world begin to wonder whether we were first in science. We're first in other areas of science but in space
column19: which is the new science
column20: we're not first.

column4: I naturally am aware of it
column5: because I
column6: of course
column7: pay attention to everything Senator Kennedy says
column8: as well as Senator Fulbright. Now
column9: in this connection I want to point out that the facts simply aren't as stated. First of all
column10: the report to which Senator Kennedy refers is one that was made many
column11: many months ago and related particularly to the uh - period immediately after Sputnik. Second
column12: as far as this report is concerned
column13: I would have no objection to having it made public. Third
column14: I would say this with regard to this report
column15: with regard to Gallup Polls of prestige abroad and everything else that we've been hearing about ""what about American prestige abroad"": America's prestige abroad will be just as high as the spokesmen for America allow it to be. Now
column16: when we have a presidential candidate
column17: for example - Senator Kennedy - stating over and over again that the United States is second in space and the fact of the matter is that the space score today is twenty-eight to eight - we've had twenty-eight successful shots
column18: they've had eight; when he states that we're second in education
column19: and I have seen Soviet education and I've seen ours
column20: and we're not; that we're second in science because they may be ahead in one area or another
column21: when overall we're way ahead of the Soviet Union and all other countries in science; when he says as he did in January of this year that we have the worst slums
column22: that we have the most crowded schools; when he says that seventeen million people go to bed hungry every night; when he makes statements like this
column23: what does this do to American prestige? Well
column24: it can only have the effect certainly of reducing it. Well let me make one thing clear. Senator Kennedy has a responsibility to criticize those things that are wrong
column25: but he has also a responsibility to be right in his criticism. Every one of these items that I have mentioned he's been wrong - dead wrong. And for that reason he has contributed to any lack of prestige. Finally
column26: let me say this: as far as prestige is concerned
column27: the first place it would show up would be in the United Nations. Now Senator Kennedy has referred to the vote on Communist China. Let's look at the vote on Hungary. There we got more votes for condemning Hungary and looking into that situation than we got the last year. Let's look at the reaction eh - reaction to Khrushchev and Eisenhower at the last U.N. session. Did Khrushchev gain because he took his shoe off and pounded the table and shouted and insulted? Not at all. The President gained. America gained by continuing the dignity
column28: the decency that has characterized us and it's that that keeps the prestige of America up
column29: not running down America the way Senator Kennedy has been running her down.

column1: I really don't need uh - Mr. Nixon to tell me about what my responsibilities are as a citizen. I've served this country for fourteen years in the Congress and before that in the service. I've just as high a devotion
column2: just as high an opinion. What I downgrade
column4: is the leadership the country is getting
column5: not the country. Now I didn't make most of the statements that you said I made. The s- I believe the Soviet Union is first in outer space. We have - may have made more shots but the size of their rocket thrust and all the rest - you yourself said to Khrushchev
column6: ""You may be ahead of us in rocket thrust but we're ahead of you in color television"" in your famous discussion in the kitchen. I think that color television is not as important as rocket thrust. Secondly
column7: I didn't say we had the worst slums in the world. I said we had too many slums. And that they are bad
column8: and we ought to do something about them
column9: and we ought to support housing legislation which this Administration has opposed. I didn't say we had the worst education in the world. What I said was that ten years ago
column10: we were producing twice as many scientists and engineers as the Soviet Union and today they're producing twice as many as we are
column11: and that this affects our security around the world. And fourth
column12: I believe that the polls and other studies and votes in the United Nations and anyone reading the paper and any citizen of the United States must come to the conclusion that the United States no longer carries the same image of a vital society on the move with its brightest days ahead as it carried a decade or two decades ago. Part of that is because we've stood still here at home
column13: because we haven't met our problems in the United States
column14: because we haven't had a moving economy. Part of that
column15: as the Gallup Polls show
column16: is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space. Mr. George Allen
column17: head of your Information Service
column18: has said that that made the people of the world begin to wonder whether we were first in science. We're first in other areas of science but in space
column19: which is the new science
column20: we're not first.

column4: I naturally am aware of it
column5: because I
column6: of course
column7: pay attention to everything Senator Kennedy says
column8: as well as Senator Fulbright. Now
column9: in this connection I want to point out that the facts simply aren't as stated. First of all
column10: the report to which Senator Kennedy refers is one that was made many
column11: many months ago and related particularly to the uh - period immediately after Sputnik. Second
column12: as far as this report is concerned
column13: I would have no objection to having it made public. Third
column14: I would say this with regard to this report
column15: with regard to Gallup Polls of prestige abroad and everything else that we've been hearing about ""what about American prestige abroad"": America's prestige abroad will be just as high as the spokesmen for America allow it to be. Now
column16: when we have a presidential candidate
column17: for example - Senator Kennedy - stating over and over again that the United States is second in space and the fact of the matter is that the space score today is twenty-eight to eight - we've had twenty-eight successful shots
column18: they've had eight; when he states that we're second in education
column19: and I have seen Soviet education and I've seen ours
column20: and we're not; that we're second in science because they may be ahead in one area or another
column21: when overall we're way ahead of the Soviet Union and all other countries in science; when he says as he did in January of this year that we have the worst slums
column22: that we have the most crowded schools; when he says that seventeen million people go to bed hungry every night; when he makes statements like this
column23: what does this do to American prestige? Well
column24: it can only have the effect certainly of reducing it. Well let me make one thing clear. Senator Kennedy has a responsibility to criticize those things that are wrong
column25: but he has also a responsibility to be right in his criticism. Every one of these items that I have mentioned he's been wrong - dead wrong. And for that reason he has contributed to any lack of prestige. Finally
column26: let me say this: as far as prestige is concerned
column27: the first place it would show up would be in the United Nations. Now Senator Kennedy has referred to the vote on Communist China. Let's look at the vote on Hungary. There we got more votes for condemning Hungary and looking into that situation than we got the last year. Let's look at the reaction eh - reaction to Khrushchev and Eisenhower at the last U.N. session. Did Khrushchev gain because he took his shoe off and pounded the table and shouted and insulted? Not at all. The President gained. America gained by continuing the dignity
column28: the decency that has characterized us and it's that that keeps the prestige of America up
column29: not running down America the way Senator Kennedy has been running her down.

column1: I really don't need uh - Mr. Nixon to tell me about what my responsibilities are as a citizen. I've served this country for fourteen years in the Congress and before that in the service. I've just as high a devotion
column2: just as high an opinion. What I downgrade
column4: is the leadership the country is getting
column5: not the country. Now I didn't make most of the statements that you said I made. The s- I believe the Soviet Union is first in outer space. We have - may have made more shots but the size of their rocket thrust and all the rest - you yourself said to Khrushchev
column6: ""You may be ahead of us in rocket thrust but we're ahead of you in color television"" in your famous discussion in the kitchen. I think that color television is not as important as rocket thrust. Secondly
column7: I didn't say we had the worst slums in the world. I said we had too many slums. And that they are bad
column8: and we ought to do something about them
column9: and we ought to support housing legislation which this Administration has opposed. I didn't say we had the worst education in the world. What I said was that ten years ago
column10: we were producing twice as many scientists and engineers as the Soviet Union and today they're producing twice as many as we are
column11: and that this affects our security around the world. And fourth
column12: I believe that the polls and other studies and votes in the United Nations and anyone reading the paper and any citizen of the United States must come to the conclusion that the United States no longer carries the same image of a vital society on the move with its brightest days ahead as it carried a decade or two decades ago. Part of that is because we've stood still here at home
column13: because we haven't met our problems in the United States
column14: because we haven't had a moving economy. Part of that
column15: as the Gallup Polls show
column16: is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space. Mr. George Allen
column17: head of your Information Service
column18: has said that that made the people of the world begin to wonder whether we were first in science. We're first in other areas of science but in space
column19: which is the new science
column20: we're not first.

column4: I naturally am aware of it
column5: because I
column6: of course
column7: pay attention to everything Senator Kennedy says
column8: as well as Senator Fulbright. Now
column9: in this connection I want to point out that the facts simply aren't as stated. First of all
column10: the report to which Senator Kennedy refers is one that was made many
column11: many months ago and related particularly to the uh - period immediately after Sputnik. Second
column12: as far as this report is concerned
column13: I would have no objection to having it made public. Third
column14: I would say this with regard to this report
column15: with regard to Gallup Polls of prestige abroad and everything else that we've been hearing about ""what about American prestige abroad"": America's prestige abroad will be just as high as the spokesmen for America allow it to be. Now
column16: when we have a presidential candidate
column17: for example - Senator Kennedy - stating over and over again that the United States is second in space and the fact of the matter is that the space score today is twenty-eight to eight - we've had twenty-eight successful shots
column18: they've had eight; when he states that we're second in education
column19: and I have seen Soviet education and I've seen ours
column20: and we're not; that we're second in science because they may be ahead in one area or another
column21: when overall we're way ahead of the Soviet Union and all other countries in science; when he says as he did in January of this year that we have the worst slums
column22: that we have the most crowded schools; when he says that seventeen million people go to bed hungry every night; when he makes statements like this
column23: what does this do to American prestige? Well
column24: it can only have the effect certainly of reducing it. Well let me make one thing clear. Senator Kennedy has a responsibility to criticize those things that are wrong
column25: but he has also a responsibility to be right in his criticism. Every one of these items that I have mentioned he's been wrong - dead wrong. And for that reason he has contributed to any lack of prestige. Finally
column26: let me say this: as far as prestige is concerned
column27: the first place it would show up would be in the United Nations. Now Senator Kennedy has referred to the vote on Communist China. Let's look at the vote on Hungary. There we got more votes for condemning Hungary and looking into that situation than we got the last year. Let's look at the reaction eh - reaction to Khrushchev and Eisenhower at the last U.N. session. Did Khrushchev gain because he took his shoe off and pounded the table and shouted and insulted? Not at all. The President gained. America gained by continuing the dignity
column28: the decency that has characterized us and it's that that keeps the prestige of America up
column29: not running down America the way Senator Kennedy has been running her down.

column1: I really don't need uh - Mr. Nixon to tell me about what my responsibilities are as a citizen. I've served this country for fourteen years in the Congress and before that in the service. I've just as high a devotion
column2: just as high an opinion. What I downgrade
column4: is the leadership the country is getting
column5: not the country. Now I didn't make most of the statements that you said I made. The s- I believe the Soviet Union is first in outer space. We have - may have made more shots but the size of their rocket thrust and all the rest - you yourself said to Khrushchev
column6: ""You may be ahead of us in rocket thrust but we're ahead of you in color television"" in your famous discussion in the kitchen. I think that color television is not as important as rocket thrust. Secondly
column7: I didn't say we had the worst slums in the world. I said we had too many slums. And that they are bad
column8: and we ought to do something about them
column9: and we ought to support housing legislation which this Administration has opposed. I didn't say we had the worst education in the world. What I said was that ten years ago
column10: we were producing twice as many scientists and engineers as the Soviet Union and today they're producing twice as many as we are
column11: and that this affects our security around the world. And fourth
column12: I believe that the polls and other studies and votes in the United Nations and anyone reading the paper and any citizen of the United States must come to the conclusion that the United States no longer carries the same image of a vital society on the move with its brightest days ahead as it carried a decade or two decades ago. Part of that is because we've stood still here at home
column13: because we haven't met our problems in the United States
column14: because we haven't had a moving economy. Part of that
column15: as the Gallup Polls show
column16: is because the Soviet Union made a breakthrough in outer space. Mr. George Allen
column17: head of your Information Service
column18: has said that that made the people of the world begin to wonder whether we were first in science. We're first in other areas of science but in space
column19: which is the new science
column20: we're not first.

column18: ""Now

column3: 6)	" Well the conditions I laid out in one of our previous television debates
column4: and it's rather difficult to be much more specific than that. Uh - First of all
column5: we have to have adequate preparation for a summit conference. This means at the secretary of state level and at the ambassadorial level. By adequate preparation I mean that at that level we must prepare an agenda
column6: an agenda agreed upon with the approval of the heads of state involved. Now this agenda should delineate those issues on which there is a possibility of some agreement or negotiation. I don't believe we should go to a summit conference unless we have such an agenda
column7: unless we have some reasonable insur- assurance from Mr. Khrushchev that he intends seriously to negotiate on those points. Now this may seem like a rigid
column8: inflexible position. But let's look at the other side of the coin. If we build up the hopes of the world by having a summit conference that is not adequately prepared
column9: and then
column10: if Mr. Khrushchev finds some excuse for breaking it up - as he did this one - because he isn't going to get his way - we'd set back the cause of peace. We do not help it. We can
column11: in other words
column12: negotiate many of these items of difference between us without going to the summit. I think we have to make a greater effort than we have been making at the secretary of state level
column13: at the ambassadorial level
column14: to work out the differences that we have. And so far as the summit conference is concerned
column15: it should only be entered in upon
column16: it should only be agreed upon
column17: if the negotiations have reached the point that we have some reasonable assurance that something is going to come out of it
column18: other than some phony spirit - a spirit of Geneva
column19: or Camp David
column20: or whatever it is. When I say ""phony spirit
column21: I mean phony
column22: not because the spirit is not good on our side
column23: but because the Soviet Union simply doesn't intend to carry out what they say. Now
column24: these are the conditions that I can lay out. I cannot be more precise than that
column25: because until we see what Mr. Khrushchev does and what he says uh - we cannot indicate what our plans will be.

column2: I think the president of the United States last winter indicated that before he'd go to the summit in May he did last fall
column3: he indicated that there should be some agenda
column4: that there should be some prior agreement. He hoped that there would be uh - b- be an agreement in part in disarmament. He also expressed the hope that there should be some understanding of the general situation in Berlin. The Soviet Union refused to agree to that
column5: and we went to the summit and it was disastrous. I believe we should not go to the summit until there is some reason to believe that a meeting of minds can be obtained on either Berlin
column6: outer space
column7: or general disarmament - including nuclear testing. In addition
column8: I believe the next president in January and February should go to work in building the strength of the United States. The Soviet Union does understand strength. We arm to parley
column9: Winston Churchill said ten years ago. If we are strong
column10: particularly as we face a crisis over Berlin - which we may in the spring
column11: or in the winter - it's important that we maintain our determination here; that we indicate that we're building our strength; that we are determined to protect our position; that we're determined to protect our commitment. And then I believe we should indicate our desire to live at peace with the world. But until we're strong here
column12: until we're moving here
column13: I believe a summit could not be successful. I hope that before we do meet
column14: there will be preliminary agreements on those four questions
column15: or at least two of them
column16: or even one of them
column17: which would warrant such a meeting. I think if we had stuck by that position last winter
column18: we would have been in a better position in May.

column4: and of course the most vulnerable area is - I have felt
column5: has been Eastern Europe. I've been critical of the Administration's failure to suggest policies which would make it possible for us to establish
column6: for example
column7: closer relations with Poland
column8: particularly after the fifty-five-fifty-six period and the Hungarian revolution. We indicated at that time that we were not going to intervene militarily. But there was a period there when Poland demonstrated a national independence and even the Polish government moved some differn- di- distance away from the Soviet Union. I suggested that we amend our legislation so that we could enjoy closer economic ties. We received the support first of the Administration and then not
column9: and we were defeated by one vote in the Senate. We passed the bill in the Senate this year but it didn't pass the House. I would say Eastern Europe is the area of vulnerability of the uh - s- of the Soviet Union. Secondly
column10: the relations between Russia and China. They are now engaged in a debate over whether war is the means of Communizing the world or whether they should use subversion
column11: infiltration
column12: economic struggles and all the rest. No one can say what that course of action will be
column13: but I think the next president of the United States should watch it carefully. If those two powers should split
column14: it could have great effects throughout the entire world. Thirdly
column15: I believe that India represents a great area for affirmative action by the free world. India started from about the same place that China did. Chinese Communists have been moving ahead the last ten years. India under a free society has been making some progress. But if India does not succeed - with her four hundred and fifty million people
column16: if she can't make freedom work - then people around the world are going to determine - particularly in the underdeveloped world - that the only way that they can develop their resources is through the Communist system. Fourth
column17: let me say that in Africa
column18: Asia
column19: Latin America
column20: Eastern Europe
column21: the great force on our side is the desire of people to be free. This has expressed itself in the revolts in Eastern Europe. It's expressed itself in the desire of the people of Africa to be independent of Western Europe. They want to be free. And my judgment is that they don't want to give their freedom up to become Communists. They want to stay free
column22: independent perhaps of us
column23: but certainly independent of the Communists. And I believe if we identify ourselves with that force
column24: if we identify ourselves with it as Lincoln
column25: as Wilson did
column26: as Franklin Roosevelt did
column27: if we become known as the friend of freedom
column28: sustaining freedom
column29: helping freedom
column30: helping these people in the fight against poverty and ignorance and disease
column31: helping them build their lives
column32: I believe in Latin America
column33: Africa
column35: eventually in the Eastern Europe and the Middle East
column37: we can strengthen freedom. We can make it move. We can put the Communists on the defensive.

column3: when I talked to Mr. Gomulka
column4: the present leader of Poland
column5: for six hours in Warsaw last year
column6: I learned something about their problems and particularly his. Right under the Soviet gun
column7: with Soviet troops there
column8: he is in a very difficult position in taking anything independent
column9: a position which would be independent of the Soviet Union. And yet let's just see what we've done for Poland
column10: A half a billion dollars worth of aid has gone to Poland
column11: primarily economic
column12: primarily to go to the people of Poland. This should continue and it can be stepped up to give them hope and to keep alive the hope for freedom that I can testify they have so deeply within them. In addition we can have more exchange with Poland or with any other of the Iron Curtain countries which show some desire to take a different path than the path that has been taken by the ones that are complete satellites of the Soviet Union. Now as far as the balance of the world is concerned
column13: I of course don't have as much time as Senator Kennedy had. I would just like to s- add this one point. If we are going to have the initiative in the world
column14: we must remember that the people of Africa and Asia and Latin America don't want to be pawns simply in a struggle between two great powers - the Soviet Union and the United States. We have to let them know that we want to help them
column15: not because we're simply trying to save our own skins
column16: not because we're simply trying to fight Communism; but because we care for them
column17: because we stand for freedom
column18: because if there were no Communism in the world
column19: we would still fight poverty and misery and disease and tyranny. If we can get that across to the people of these countries
column20: in this decade of the sixties
column21: the struggle for freedom will be won.

column4: and of course the most vulnerable area is - I have felt
column5: has been Eastern Europe. I've been critical of the Administration's failure to suggest policies which would make it possible for us to establish
column6: for example
column7: closer relations with Poland
column8: particularly after the fifty-five-fifty-six period and the Hungarian revolution. We indicated at that time that we were not going to intervene militarily. But there was a period there when Poland demonstrated a national independence and even the Polish government moved some differn- di- distance away from the Soviet Union. I suggested that we amend our legislation so that we could enjoy closer economic ties. We received the support first of the Administration and then not
column9: and we were defeated by one vote in the Senate. We passed the bill in the Senate this year but it didn't pass the House. I would say Eastern Europe is the area of vulnerability of the uh - s- of the Soviet Union. Secondly
column10: the relations between Russia and China. They are now engaged in a debate over whether war is the means of Communizing the world or whether they should use subversion
column11: infiltration
column12: economic struggles and all the rest. No one can say what that course of action will be
column13: but I think the next president of the United States should watch it carefully. If those two powers should split
column14: it could have great effects throughout the entire world. Thirdly
column15: I believe that India represents a great area for affirmative action by the free world. India started from about the same place that China did. Chinese Communists have been moving ahead the last ten years. India under a free society has been making some progress. But if India does not succeed - with her four hundred and fifty million people
column16: if she can't make freedom work - then people around the world are going to determine - particularly in the underdeveloped world - that the only way that they can develop their resources is through the Communist system. Fourth
column17: let me say that in Africa
column18: Asia
column19: Latin America
column20: Eastern Europe
column21: the great force on our side is the desire of people to be free. This has expressed itself in the revolts in Eastern Europe. It's expressed itself in the desire of the people of Africa to be independent of Western Europe. They want to be free. And my judgment is that they don't want to give their freedom up to become Communists. They want to stay free
column22: independent perhaps of us
column23: but certainly independent of the Communists. And I believe if we identify ourselves with that force
column24: if we identify ourselves with it as Lincoln
column25: as Wilson did
column26: as Franklin Roosevelt did
column27: if we become known as the friend of freedom
column28: sustaining freedom
column29: helping freedom
column30: helping these people in the fight against poverty and ignorance and disease
column31: helping them build their lives
column32: I believe in Latin America
column33: Africa
column35: eventually in the Eastern Europe and the Middle East
column37: we can strengthen freedom. We can make it move. We can put the Communists on the defensive.

column3: when I talked to Mr. Gomulka
column4: the present leader of Poland
column5: for six hours in Warsaw last year
column6: I learned something about their problems and particularly his. Right under the Soviet gun
column7: with Soviet troops there
column8: he is in a very difficult position in taking anything independent
column9: a position which would be independent of the Soviet Union. And yet let's just see what we've done for Poland
column10: A half a billion dollars worth of aid has gone to Poland
column11: primarily economic
column12: primarily to go to the people of Poland. This should continue and it can be stepped up to give them hope and to keep alive the hope for freedom that I can testify they have so deeply within them. In addition we can have more exchange with Poland or with any other of the Iron Curtain countries which show some desire to take a different path than the path that has been taken by the ones that are complete satellites of the Soviet Union. Now as far as the balance of the world is concerned
column13: I of course don't have as much time as Senator Kennedy had. I would just like to s- add this one point. If we are going to have the initiative in the world
column14: we must remember that the people of Africa and Asia and Latin America don't want to be pawns simply in a struggle between two great powers - the Soviet Union and the United States. We have to let them know that we want to help them
column15: not because we're simply trying to save our own skins
column16: not because we're simply trying to fight Communism; but because we care for them
column17: because we stand for freedom
column18: because if there were no Communism in the world
column19: we would still fight poverty and misery and disease and tyranny. If we can get that across to the people of these countries
column20: in this decade of the sixties
column21: the struggle for freedom will be won.

column4: and of course the most vulnerable area is - I have felt
column5: has been Eastern Europe. I've been critical of the Administration's failure to suggest policies which would make it possible for us to establish
column6: for example
column7: closer relations with Poland
column8: particularly after the fifty-five-fifty-six period and the Hungarian revolution. We indicated at that time that we were not going to intervene militarily. But there was a period there when Poland demonstrated a national independence and even the Polish government moved some differn- di- distance away from the Soviet Union. I suggested that we amend our legislation so that we could enjoy closer economic ties. We received the support first of the Administration and then not
column9: and we were defeated by one vote in the Senate. We passed the bill in the Senate this year but it didn't pass the House. I would say Eastern Europe is the area of vulnerability of the uh - s- of the Soviet Union. Secondly
column10: the relations between Russia and China. They are now engaged in a debate over whether war is the means of Communizing the world or whether they should use subversion
column11: infiltration
column12: economic struggles and all the rest. No one can say what that course of action will be
column13: but I think the next president of the United States should watch it carefully. If those two powers should split
column14: it could have great effects throughout the entire world. Thirdly
column15: I believe that India represents a great area for affirmative action by the free world. India started from about the same place that China did. Chinese Communists have been moving ahead the last ten years. India under a free society has been making some progress. But if India does not succeed - with her four hundred and fifty million people
column16: if she can't make freedom work - then people around the world are going to determine - particularly in the underdeveloped world - that the only way that they can develop their resources is through the Communist system. Fourth
column17: let me say that in Africa
column18: Asia
column19: Latin America
column20: Eastern Europe
column21: the great force on our side is the desire of people to be free. This has expressed itself in the revolts in Eastern Europe. It's expressed itself in the desire of the people of Africa to be independent of Western Europe. They want to be free. And my judgment is that they don't want to give their freedom up to become Communists. They want to stay free
column22: independent perhaps of us
column23: but certainly independent of the Communists. And I believe if we identify ourselves with that force
column24: if we identify ourselves with it as Lincoln
column25: as Wilson did
column26: as Franklin Roosevelt did
column27: if we become known as the friend of freedom
column28: sustaining freedom
column29: helping freedom
column30: helping these people in the fight against poverty and ignorance and disease
column31: helping them build their lives
column32: I believe in Latin America
column33: Africa
column35: eventually in the Eastern Europe and the Middle East
column37: we can strengthen freedom. We can make it move. We can put the Communists on the defensive.

column3: when I talked to Mr. Gomulka
column4: the present leader of Poland
column5: for six hours in Warsaw last year
column6: I learned something about their problems and particularly his. Right under the Soviet gun
column7: with Soviet troops there
column8: he is in a very difficult position in taking anything independent
column9: a position which would be independent of the Soviet Union. And yet let's just see what we've done for Poland
column10: A half a billion dollars worth of aid has gone to Poland
column11: primarily economic
column12: primarily to go to the people of Poland. This should continue and it can be stepped up to give them hope and to keep alive the hope for freedom that I can testify they have so deeply within them. In addition we can have more exchange with Poland or with any other of the Iron Curtain countries which show some desire to take a different path than the path that has been taken by the ones that are complete satellites of the Soviet Union. Now as far as the balance of the world is concerned
column13: I of course don't have as much time as Senator Kennedy had. I would just like to s- add this one point. If we are going to have the initiative in the world
column14: we must remember that the people of Africa and Asia and Latin America don't want to be pawns simply in a struggle between two great powers - the Soviet Union and the United States. We have to let them know that we want to help them
column15: not because we're simply trying to save our own skins
column16: not because we're simply trying to fight Communism; but because we care for them
column17: because we stand for freedom
column18: because if there were no Communism in the world
column19: we would still fight poverty and misery and disease and tyranny. If we can get that across to the people of these countries
column20: in this decade of the sixties
column21: the struggle for freedom will be won.

column4: and of course the most vulnerable area is - I have felt
column5: has been Eastern Europe. I've been critical of the Administration's failure to suggest policies which would make it possible for us to establish
column6: for example
column7: closer relations with Poland
column8: particularly after the fifty-five-fifty-six period and the Hungarian revolution. We indicated at that time that we were not going to intervene militarily. But there was a period there when Poland demonstrated a national independence and even the Polish government moved some differn- di- distance away from the Soviet Union. I suggested that we amend our legislation so that we could enjoy closer economic ties. We received the support first of the Administration and then not
column9: and we were defeated by one vote in the Senate. We passed the bill in the Senate this year but it didn't pass the House. I would say Eastern Europe is the area of vulnerability of the uh - s- of the Soviet Union. Secondly
column10: the relations between Russia and China. They are now engaged in a debate over whether war is the means of Communizing the world or whether they should use subversion
column11: infiltration
column12: economic struggles and all the rest. No one can say what that course of action will be
column13: but I think the next president of the United States should watch it carefully. If those two powers should split
column14: it could have great effects throughout the entire world. Thirdly
column15: I believe that India represents a great area for affirmative action by the free world. India started from about the same place that China did. Chinese Communists have been moving ahead the last ten years. India under a free society has been making some progress. But if India does not succeed - with her four hundred and fifty million people
column16: if she can't make freedom work - then people around the world are going to determine - particularly in the underdeveloped world - that the only way that they can develop their resources is through the Communist system. Fourth
column17: let me say that in Africa
column18: Asia
column19: Latin America
column20: Eastern Europe
column21: the great force on our side is the desire of people to be free. This has expressed itself in the revolts in Eastern Europe. It's expressed itself in the desire of the people of Africa to be independent of Western Europe. They want to be free. And my judgment is that they don't want to give their freedom up to become Communists. They want to stay free
column22: independent perhaps of us
column23: but certainly independent of the Communists. And I believe if we identify ourselves with that force
column24: if we identify ourselves with it as Lincoln
column25: as Wilson did
column26: as Franklin Roosevelt did
column27: if we become known as the friend of freedom
column28: sustaining freedom
column29: helping freedom
column30: helping these people in the fight against poverty and ignorance and disease
column31: helping them build their lives
column32: I believe in Latin America
column33: Africa
column35: eventually in the Eastern Europe and the Middle East
column37: we can strengthen freedom. We can make it move. We can put the Communists on the defensive.

column3: when I talked to Mr. Gomulka
column4: the present leader of Poland
column5: for six hours in Warsaw last year
column6: I learned something about their problems and particularly his. Right under the Soviet gun
column7: with Soviet troops there
column8: he is in a very difficult position in taking anything independent
column9: a position which would be independent of the Soviet Union. And yet let's just see what we've done for Poland
column10: A half a billion dollars worth of aid has gone to Poland
column11: primarily economic
column12: primarily to go to the people of Poland. This should continue and it can be stepped up to give them hope and to keep alive the hope for freedom that I can testify they have so deeply within them. In addition we can have more exchange with Poland or with any other of the Iron Curtain countries which show some desire to take a different path than the path that has been taken by the ones that are complete satellites of the Soviet Union. Now as far as the balance of the world is concerned
column13: I of course don't have as much time as Senator Kennedy had. I would just like to s- add this one point. If we are going to have the initiative in the world
column14: we must remember that the people of Africa and Asia and Latin America don't want to be pawns simply in a struggle between two great powers - the Soviet Union and the United States. We have to let them know that we want to help them
column15: not because we're simply trying to save our own skins
column16: not because we're simply trying to fight Communism; but because we care for them
column17: because we stand for freedom
column18: because if there were no Communism in the world
column19: we would still fight poverty and misery and disease and tyranny. If we can get that across to the people of these countries
column20: in this decade of the sixties
column21: the struggle for freedom will be won.

column3: 8)	" I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error. He says he supports the President's position. He says that he voted for the resolution. Well just let me point this out; he voted for the resolution in 1955 which gave the president the power to use the forces of the United States to defend Formosa and the offshore islands. But he also voted then for an amendment - which was lost
column4: fortunately - an amendment which would have drawn a line and left out those islands and denied the p- right to the president to defend those islands if he thought that it was an attack on Formosa. He repeated that error in 1959
column5: in the speech that he made. He repeated it again in a television debate that we had. Now
column6: my point is this: Senator Kennedy has got to be consistent here. Either he's for the President and he's against the position that those who opposed the President in fifty-five and fifty-nine - and the Senator's position itself
column7: stated the other day in our debate - either he is for the President and against that position or we simply have a disagreement here that must continue to be debated. Now if the Senator in his answer to this question will say ""I now will depart
column8: or retract my previous views; I think I was wrong in I 955; I think I was wrong in 1959; and I think I was wrong in our television debate to say that we should draw a line leaving out Quemoy and Matsu - draw a line in effect abandoning these islands to the Communists;"" then this will be right out of the campaign because there will be no issue between us. I support the President's position. I have always opposed drawing a line. I have opposed drawing a line because I know that the moment you draw a line
column9: that is an encouragement for the Communists to attack - to step up their blackmail and to force you into the war that none of us want. And so I would hope that Senator Kennedy in his answer today would clear it up. It isn't enough for him to say ""I support the President's position
column10: that I voted for the resolution."" Of course
column11: he voted for the resolution - it was virtually unanimous. But the point is
column12: what about his error in voting for the amendment
column13: which was not adopted
column14: and then persisting in it in fifty-nine
column15: persisting in it in the debate. It's very simple for him to clear it up. He can say now that he no longer believes that a line should be drawn leaving these islands out of the perimeter of defense. If he says that
column16: this issue will not be discussed in the campaign.

column3: to go back to 1955. The resolution commits the president in the United States
column4: which I supported
column5: to defend uh - Formosa
column6: the Pescadores
column7: and if it was his military judgment
column8: these islands. Then the President sent a mission
column9: composed of Admiral Radford and Mr. Robertson
column10: to persuade Chiang Kai-shek in the spring of fifty-five to withdraw from the two islands
column11: because they were exposed. The President was unsuccessful; Chiang Kai-shek would not withdraw. I refer to the fact that in 1958
column12: as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column13: I'm very familiar with the position that the United States took in negotiating with the Chinese Communists on these two islands. General Twining
column14: in January
column15: fifty-nine
column16: described the position of the United States. The position of the United States has been that this build-up
column17: in the words of the president
column18: has been foolish. Mr. Herter has said these islands are indefensible. Chiang Kai-shek will not withdraw. Because he will not withdraw
column19: because he's committed to these islands
column20: because we've been unable to persuade him to withdraw
column21: we are in a very difficult position. And therefore
column22: the President's judgment has been that we should defend the islands if
column23: in his military judgment and the judgment of the commander in the field
column24: the attack on these islands should be part of an overall attack on Formosa. I support that. In view of the difficulties we've had with the islands
column25: in view of the difficulties and disputes we've had with Chiang Kai-shek
column26: that's the only position we can take. That's not the position you took
column27: however. The first position you took
column28: when this matter first came up
column29: was that we should draw the line and commit ourselves
column30: as a matter of principle
column31: to defend these islands. Not as part of the defense of Formosa and the Pescadores. You showed no recognition of the Administration program to try to persuade Chiang Kai-shek for the last five years to withdraw from the islands. And I challenge you tonight to deny that the Administration has sent at least several missions to persuade Chiang Kai-shek's withdrawal from these islands.

column3: 8)	" I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error. He says he supports the President's position. He says that he voted for the resolution. Well just let me point this out; he voted for the resolution in 1955 which gave the president the power to use the forces of the United States to defend Formosa and the offshore islands. But he also voted then for an amendment - which was lost
column4: fortunately - an amendment which would have drawn a line and left out those islands and denied the p- right to the president to defend those islands if he thought that it was an attack on Formosa. He repeated that error in 1959
column5: in the speech that he made. He repeated it again in a television debate that we had. Now
column6: my point is this: Senator Kennedy has got to be consistent here. Either he's for the President and he's against the position that those who opposed the President in fifty-five and fifty-nine - and the Senator's position itself
column7: stated the other day in our debate - either he is for the President and against that position or we simply have a disagreement here that must continue to be debated. Now if the Senator in his answer to this question will say ""I now will depart
column8: or retract my previous views; I think I was wrong in I 955; I think I was wrong in 1959; and I think I was wrong in our television debate to say that we should draw a line leaving out Quemoy and Matsu - draw a line in effect abandoning these islands to the Communists;"" then this will be right out of the campaign because there will be no issue between us. I support the President's position. I have always opposed drawing a line. I have opposed drawing a line because I know that the moment you draw a line
column9: that is an encouragement for the Communists to attack - to step up their blackmail and to force you into the war that none of us want. And so I would hope that Senator Kennedy in his answer today would clear it up. It isn't enough for him to say ""I support the President's position
column10: that I voted for the resolution."" Of course
column11: he voted for the resolution - it was virtually unanimous. But the point is
column12: what about his error in voting for the amendment
column13: which was not adopted
column14: and then persisting in it in fifty-nine
column15: persisting in it in the debate. It's very simple for him to clear it up. He can say now that he no longer believes that a line should be drawn leaving these islands out of the perimeter of defense. If he says that
column16: this issue will not be discussed in the campaign.

column13: I'm very familiar with the position that the United States took in negotiating with the Chinese Communists on these two islands. General Twining
column14: in January

column17: in the words of the president

column19: because he's committed to these islands
column20: because we've been unable to persuade him to withdraw

You showed no recognition of the Administration program to try to persuade Chiang Kai-shek for the last five years to withdraw from the islands. And I challenge you tonight to deny that the Administration has sent at least several missions to persuade Chiang Kai-shek's withdrawal from these islands.

column11: he voted for the resolution - it was virtually unanimous. But the point is
column12: what about his error in voting for the amendment
column13: which was not adopted
column14: and then persisting in it in fifty-nine
column15: persisting in it in the debate. It's very simple for him to clear it up. He can say now that he no longer believes that a line should be drawn leaving these islands out of the perimeter of defense. If he says that
column16: this issue will not be discussed in the campaign.

column3: to go back to 1955. The resolution commits the president in the United States
column4: which I supported
column5: to defend uh - Formosa
column6: the Pescadores
column7: and if it was his military judgment
column8: these islands. Then the President sent a mission
column9: composed of Admiral Radford and Mr. Robertson
column10: to persuade Chiang Kai-shek in the spring of fifty-five to withdraw from the two islands
column11: because they were exposed. The President was unsuccessful; Chiang Kai-shek would not withdraw. I refer to the fact that in 1958
column12: as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column13: I'm very familiar with the position that the United States took in negotiating with the Chinese Communists on these two islands. General Twining
column14: in January
column15: fifty-nine
column16: described the position of the United States. The position of the United States has been that this build-up
column17: in the words of the president
column18: has been foolish. Mr. Herter has said these islands are indefensible. Chiang Kai-shek will not withdraw. Because he will not withdraw
column19: because he's committed to these islands
column20: because we've been unable to persuade him to withdraw
column21: we are in a very difficult position. And therefore
column22: the President's judgment has been that we should defend the islands if
column23: in his military judgment and the judgment of the commander in the field
column24: the attack on these islands should be part of an overall attack on Formosa. I support that. In view of the difficulties we've had with the islands
column25: in view of the difficulties and disputes we've had with Chiang Kai-shek
column26: that's the only position we can take. That's not the position you took
column27: however. The first position you took
column28: when this matter first came up
column29: was that we should draw the line and commit ourselves
column30: as a matter of principle
column31: to defend these islands. Not as part of the defense of Formosa and the Pescadores. You showed no recognition of the Administration program to try to persuade Chiang Kai-shek for the last five years to withdraw from the islands. And I challenge you tonight to deny that the Administration has sent at least several missions to persuade Chiang Kai-shek's withdrawal from these islands.

column3: 8)	" I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error. He says he supports the President's position. He says that he voted for the resolution. Well just let me point this out; he voted for the resolution in 1955 which gave the president the power to use the forces of the United States to defend Formosa and the offshore islands. But he also voted then for an amendment - which was lost
column4: fortunately - an amendment which would have drawn a line and left out those islands and denied the p- right to the president to defend those islands if he thought that it was an attack on Formosa. He repeated that error in 1959
column5: in the speech that he made. He repeated it again in a television debate that we had. Now
column6: my point is this: Senator Kennedy has got to be consistent here. Either he's for the President and he's against the position that those who opposed the President in fifty-five and fifty-nine - and the Senator's position itself
column7: stated the other day in our debate - either he is for the President and against that position or we simply have a disagreement here that must continue to be debated. Now if the Senator in his answer to this question will say ""I now will depart

I support the President's position. I have always opposed drawing a line. I have opposed drawing a line because I know that the moment you draw a line

column3: 8)	" I would say that the issue will stay with us as a campaign issue just as long as Senator Kennedy persists in what I think is a fundamental error. He says he supports the President's position. He says that he voted for the resolution. Well just let me point this out; he voted for the resolution in 1955 which gave the president the power to use the forces of the United States to defend Formosa and the offshore islands. But he also voted then for an amendment - which was lost
column4: fortunately - an amendment which would have drawn a line and left out those islands and denied the p- right to the president to defend those islands if he thought that it was an attack on Formosa. He repeated that error in 1959
column5: in the speech that he made. He repeated it again in a television debate that we had. Now
column6: my point is this: Senator Kennedy has got to be consistent here. Either he's for the President and he's against the position that those who opposed the President in fifty-five and fifty-nine - and the Senator's position itself
column7: stated the other day in our debate - either he is for the President and against that position or we simply have a disagreement here that must continue to be debated. Now if the Senator in his answer to this question will say ""I now will depart
column8: or retract my previous views; I think I was wrong in I 955; I think I was wrong in 1959; and I think I was wrong in our television debate to say that we should draw a line leaving out Quemoy and Matsu - draw a line in effect abandoning these islands to the Communists;"" then this will be right out of the campaign because there will be no issue between us. I support the President's position. I have always opposed drawing a line. I have opposed drawing a line because I know that the moment you draw a line
column9: that is an encouragement for the Communists to attack - to step up their blackmail and to force you into the war that none of us want. And so I would hope that Senator Kennedy in his answer today would clear it up. It isn't enough for him to say ""I support the President's position
column10: that I voted for the resolution."" Of course
column11: he voted for the resolution - it was virtually unanimous. But the point is
column12: what about his error in voting for the amendment
column13: which was not adopted
column14: and then persisting in it in fifty-nine
column15: persisting in it in the debate. It's very simple for him to clear it up. He can say now that he no longer believes that a line should be drawn leaving these islands out of the perimeter of defense. If he says that
column16: this issue will not be discussed in the campaign.

column3: to go back to 1955. The resolution commits the president in the United States
column4: which I supported
column5: to defend uh - Formosa
column6: the Pescadores
column7: and if it was his military judgment
column8: these islands. Then the President sent a mission
column9: composed of Admiral Radford and Mr. Robertson
column10: to persuade Chiang Kai-shek in the spring of fifty-five to withdraw from the two islands
column11: because they were exposed. The President was unsuccessful; Chiang Kai-shek would not withdraw. I refer to the fact that in 1958
column12: as a member of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee
column13: I'm very familiar with the position that the United States took in negotiating with the Chinese Communists on these two islands. General Twining
column14: in January
column15: fifty-nine
column16: described the position of the United States. The position of the United States has been that this build-up
column17: in the words of the president
column18: has been foolish. Mr. Herter has said these islands are indefensible. Chiang Kai-shek will not withdraw. Because he will not withdraw
column19: because he's committed to these islands
column20: because we've been unable to persuade him to withdraw
column21: we are in a very difficult position. And therefore
column22: the President's judgment has been that we should defend the islands if
column23: in his military judgment and the judgment of the commander in the field
column24: the attack on these islands should be part of an overall attack on Formosa. I support that. In view of the difficulties we've had with the islands
column25: in view of the difficulties and disputes we've had with Chiang Kai-shek
column26: that's the only position we can take. That's not the position you took
column27: however. The first position you took
column28: when this matter first came up
column29: was that we should draw the line and commit ourselves
column30: as a matter of principle
column31: to defend these islands. Not as part of the defense of Formosa and the Pescadores. You showed no recognition of the Administration program to try to persuade Chiang Kai-shek for the last five years to withdraw from the islands. And I challenge you tonight to deny that the Administration has sent at least several missions to persuade Chiang Kai-shek's withdrawal from these islands.

column1: And that's the testimony of uh - General Twining and the Assistant Secretary of State in fifty-eight.

The position of the United States has been that this build-up, in the words of the president, has been foolish. column61: because he's committed to these islands
column62: because we've been unable to persuade him to withdraw
column63: we are in a very difficult position.""

column3: 9)	" I uh - said that I've served this country for fourteen years. I served it uh - in the war. I'm devoted to it. If I lose this election
column4: I will continue in the Senate to try to build a stronger country. But I run because I believe this year the United States has a great opportunity to make a move forward
column5: to make a determination here at home and around the world
column6: that it's going to reestablish itself as a vigorous society. My judgment is that the Republican party has stood still here in the United States
column7: and it's also stood still around the world. Uh - We're using about fifty percent of our steel capacity today. We had a recession in fifty-eight. We had a recession in fifty-four. We're not moving ahead in education the way we should. We didn't make a judgment in fifty-seven and fifty-six and fifty-five and fifty-four that outer space would be important. If we stand still here
column8: if we appoint people to ambassadorships and positions in Washington who have a status quo outlook
column9: who don't recognize that this is a revolutionary time
column10: then the United States does not maintain its influence. And if we fail
column11: the cause of freedom fails. I believe it incumbent upon the next president of the United States to get this country moving again
column12: to get our economy moving ahead
column13: to set before the American people its goals
column14: its unfinished business. And then throughout the world appoint the best people we can get
column15: ambassadors who can speak the language - no mere - not merely people who made a political contribution but who can speak the language. Bring students here; let them see what kind of a country we have. Mr. Nixon said that we should not regard them as pawns in the cold war; we should identify ourselves with them. If that were true
column16: why didn't we identify ourselves with the people of Africa? Why didn't we bring students over here? Why did we suddenly offer Congo three hundred students last June when they had the tremendous revolt? That was more than we had offered to all of Africa before from the federal government. I believe that this party - Republican party - has stood still really for twenty-five years - its leadership has. It opposed all of the programs of President Roosevelt and others - the minimum wage and for housing and economic growth and development of our natural resources
column17: the Tennessee Valley and all the rest. And I believe that if we can get a party which believes in movement
column18: which believes in going ahead
column19: then we can reestablish our position in the world - strong defense
column20: strong in economic growth
column21: justice for our people
column22: co- guarantee of constitutional rights
column23: so that people will believe that we practice what we preach
column24: and then around the world
column25: particularly to try to reestablish the atmosphere which existed in Latin America at the time of Franklin Roosevelt. He was a good neighbor in Latin America because he was a good neighbor in the United States; because they saw us as a society that was compassionate
column26: that cared about people
column27: that was moving this country ahead. I believe it my responsibility as the leader of the Democratic party in 1960 to try to warn the American people that in this crucial time we can no longer afford to stand still. We can no longer afford to be second best. I want people all over the world to look to the United States again
column28: to feel that we're on the move
column29: to feel that our high noon is in the future. I want Mr. Khrushchev to know that a new generation of Americans who fought in Europe and Italy and the Pacific for freedom in World War II have now taken over in the United States
column30: and that they're going to put this country back to work again. I don't believe that there is anything this country cannot do. I don't believe there's any burden
column31: or any responsibility
column32: that any American would not assume to protect his country
column33: to protect our security
column34: to advance the cause of freedom. And I believe it incumbent upon us now to do that. Franklin Roosevelt said in 1936 that that generation of Americans had a rendezvous with destiny. I believe in 1960 and sixty-one and two and three we have a rendezvous with destiny. And I believe it incumbent upon us to be the defenders of the United States and the defenders of freedom; and to do that
column35: we must give this country leadership and we must get America moving again.

column1: Senator Kennedy has said tonight again what he has said several times in the course of this - these debates and in the campaign
column2: that American is standing still. America is not standing still. It has not been standing still. And let's set the record straight right now by looking at the record
column3: as Al Smith used to say. He talks about housing. We built more houses in the last seven years than in any Administration and thirty percent more than in the previous Administration. We talk about schools - three times as many classrooms built in the past Administration - and Eisenhower - than under the Truman Administration. Let's talk about civil rights. More progress in the past eight years than in the whole eighty years before. He talks about the progress in the field of slum clearance and the like. We find four times as many projects undertaken and completed in this Administration than in the previous one. Anybody that says America has been standing still for the last seven and a half years hasn't been traveling in America. He's been in some other country. Let's get that straight right away. Now the second point we have to understand is this
column4: however. America has not been standing still. But America cannot stand pat. We can't stand pat for the reason that we're in a race
column5: as I've indicated. We can't stand pat because it is essential with the conflict that we have around the world that we not just hold our own
column6: that we not keep just freedom for ourselves. It is essential that we extend freedom
column7: extend it to all the world. And this means more than what we've been doing. It means keeping America even stronger militarily than she is. It means seeing that our economy moves forward even faster than it has. It means making more progress in civil rights than we have so that we can be a splendid example for all the world to see - a democracy in action at its best. Now
column8: looking at the other parts of the world - South America - talking about our record and the previous one. We had a good neighbor policy
column9: yes. It sounded fine. But let's look at it. There were eleven dictators when we came into power in 1953 in Latin America. There are only three left. Let's look at Africa. Twenty new countries in Africa during the course of this Administration. Not one of them selected a Communist government. All of them voted for freedom - a free type of government. Does this show that Communism has the bigger pull
column10: or freedom has the bigger pull? Am I trying to indicate that we have no problems in Africa or Latin America or Asia? Of course not. What I am trying to indicate is that the tide of history's on our side
column11: and that we can keep it on our side
column12: because we're on the right side. We're on the side of freedom. We're on the side of justice against the forces of slavery
column13: against the forces of injustice. But we aren't going to move America forward and we aren't going to be able to lead the world to win this struggle for freedom if we have a permanent inferiority complex about American achievements. Because we are first in the world in space
column14: as I've indicated; we are first in science; we are first in education
column15: and we're going to move even further ahead with the kind of leadership that we can provide in these years ahead. One other point I would make: what could you do? Senator Kennedy and I are candidates for the presidency of the United States. And in the years to come it will be written that one or the other of us was elected and that he was or was not a great president. What will determine whether Senator Kennedy or I
column16: if I am elected
column17: was a great president? It will not be our ambition that will determine it
column18: because greatness is not something that is written on a campaign poster. It will be determined to the extent that we represent the deepest ideals
column19: the highest feelings and faith of the American people. In other words
column20: the next president
column21: as he leads America and the free world
column22: can be only as great as the American people are great. And so I say in conclusion
column23: keep America's faith strong. See that the young people of America
column24: particularly
column25: have faith in the ideals of freedom and faith in God
column26: which distinguishes us from the atheistic materialists who oppose us.
